questions.text: Which of the following is used as nail lacquer for treatment of onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Treatment

  • Drug of choice: Terbinafine, 250mg OD x 4-6 weeks
  • Itraconazole, Griseofulin also used.

Tinea ungium: Treatment

  • Nail lacquers: single nail / cannot be given oral(Hepatitis, polypharmacy)
  • Amorolfine 5%, Ciclopirox 8%, Terbinafine 10%, Efinaconazole

Oral

  • Fingernail - 6 weeks, toenail - 12 weeks
  • Pulse therapy: itraconazole

questions.text: Dermatological manifestation of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Pellagra is a nutritional disorder caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to systemic disease with clinical manifestations from the skin, gastrointestinal tract and the nervous system
  • The pellagra syndrome has historically been characterized by the 4 D's: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia leading to Death
  • The characteristic skin rash has a typical photosensitive distribution with welldefined borders, and is mostly observed on the face, the neck - forming the so-called Casal's necklace-, the dorsa of the hands and the extensor surface of the forearms.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement - intractable diarrhea, stomatitis and glossitis,
  • Neurocognitive impairment - apathy, memory loss (dementia)
  • Niacin deficiency should especially be suspected in - corn/maize eaters, chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, malabsorption, hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis;, drugs like isoniazid, ethionamide, 6-mercaptopurine and estrogens, carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A patient presents with nail lesions. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Image - coarse irregular pitting, salmon patch, onycholysis - point to diagnosis of nail psoriasis.
  • Nail psoriasis can manifest clinically as a wide variety of nail changes, depending upon the part of the nail units affected
  • Clinical features related to nail matrix involvement are nail Pitting, red spots in the lunula, leukonychia, and crumbling of the complete nail plate.
  • The involvement of the nail bed manifests clinically as Onycholysis, splinter hemorrhages, subungual hyperkeratosis, and oil drop discoloration

questions.solution:
• Pellagra is a nutritional disorder caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to systemic disease with clinical manifestations from the skin, gastrointestinal tract and the nervous system
  • The pellagra syndrome has historically been characterized by the 4 D's: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia leading to Death
  • The characteristic skin rash has a typical photosensitive distribution with welldefined borders, and is mostly observed on the face, the neck - forming the so-called Casal's necklace-, the dorsa of the hands and the extensor surface of the forearms.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement - intractable diarrhea, stomatitis and glossitis,
  • Neurocognitive impairment - apathy, memory loss (dementia)
  • Niacin deficiency should especially be suspected in - corn/maize eaters, chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, malabsorption, hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis;, drugs like isoniazid, ethionamide, 6-mercaptopurine and estrogens, carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A sexually active patient with painful lesions on penis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described-a sexually active patient with painful lesions on the penis-are crucial for determining the diagnosis.

Diagnosis

The most likely diagnosis based on the provided options is:

a. Herpes genitalis

Supporting Information

Herpes Genitalis: This condition is caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and is characterized by painful, fluid-filled blisters or sores on the genital area. The lesions can be quite painful and are often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and lymphadenopathy.

Chancroid: While this condition also causes painful ulcers, it typically presents with soft, painful sores that can ooze pus. However, the classic presentation of herpes includes vesicular lesions that rupture to form painful ulcers.

Syphilis: Early syphilis usually presents with a painless ulcer (chancre), which does not align with the symptom of pain described.

Lymphogranuloma Venereum: This condition typically starts with a small, painless ulcer but is followed by painful lymphadenopathy rather than direct painful lesions on the penis.

Given these considerations, the correct answer to your query is:

a. Herpes genitalis.

questions.text: Sporotrichoid pattern/nodular lymphangitis is seen in all infections except
questions.solution:
Sporotrichoid lymphocutaneous infection is characterized by the appearance of subcutaneous nodules that progress along dermal and lymphatic vessels. It is also called nodular lymphangitis.

S- Sporotrichosis

T- Tuberculosis, Tularemia

A- Atypical Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium marinum)

N- Nocardiosis

Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)

Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii

It is dimorphic fungus

There are 3 types:

Histopathology shows 'Asteroid bodies'

Fish tank granuloma: (Swimming pool granuloma)

Causative organism: M. marinum

questions.text: Identify this histopathological image. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lesions of pemphigus vulgaris show suprabasal epidermal acantholysis, clefting and blister formation. The blister cavity may contain inflammatory cells including eosinophils and rounded acantholytic cells with intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm and a perinuclear halo. The floor of the blister may be lined with intact keratinocytes, the 'tombstone pattern'. Dermal changes include perivascular inflammatory infiltrate particularly with eosinophils.

Direct immunofluorescence is the most sensitive test for pemphigus. DIF patterns demonstrate intercellular immunoglobulin G (IgG) deposition in a fish net/ chicken wire/honeycomb pattern.

Leishmaniasis histology shows LD bodies

Leprosy histopathology varies according to type of leprosy.

Lepromatous leprosy - Underneath a normal epidermis and grenz zone, there are sheets or clusters of foamy macrophages. The macrophages have an abundant pink to pale cytoplasm which corresponds to numerous intracellular organisms.

Tuberculoid leprosy - There is an epithelioid granuloma throughout the dermis consisting of some Langhans giant cells, macrophages in tight clusters, and few accompanying lymphocytes. The infiltrate may extensively infiltrate peripheral nerves, vessels, the overlying epidermis.

Mycoses fungoides:

Mycosis fungoides, histopathology, is characterized by infiltrates of malignant T-cells. These are small to medium in size, and characteristically have irregular cerebriform nuclei.

In the plaque stage, the epidermis shows acanthosis with a psoriasiform hyperplasia and absent or rare spongiosis. The upper dermis may show a dense, band-like lymphocyte infiltrate with cerebriform nuclei and prominent epidermotropism

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is
questions.solution: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) used as a cosmetic preservative causes allergic contact dermatitis. It inhibits bacterial growth in cosmetic products.

questions.text: Drug of choice for disorder with subepidermal blistering with neutrophil is____
questions.solution:
Approach to immunobullous disorder:

  • Intraepidermal blister:
    • Pemphigus vulgaris/foliaceus
  • Subepidermal blister:
    • Bullous pemphigoid
    • Linear igA / CBDC (Chronic bullous disease of childhood)
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Subepidermal blister with neutrophils :
    • Linear IgA/CBDC
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis

The image is showing 'ring of jewel' appearance seen in Linear IgA/CBDC

Dapsone is drug of choice for linear IgA/CBDC

questions.text: All the following produce non scarring alopecia except?
questions.solution:
Scarring alopecia:

  • DLE
  • Lichenplanopilaris
  • SLE (Both scarring and nonscarring)
  • Pseudopalade of brocq
  • Kerion
  • Favus
  • Folliculitis

Nonscarring alopecia

  • Grey patch tinea capitis
  • Black dot tinea capitis
  • Androgenic alopecia
  • Alopecia areata
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Trichotillomania
  • Nutritional deficiency

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is characterized by band of cicatricial alopecia from anterior hairline.

Sometimes associated with madarosis (loss of eyebrow)

questions.text: What is the management for a patient who comes with the following presentation?
questions.solution:
The image is consistent with oral candidiasis, commonly seen in immunosuppressed individuals. It is typically caused by Candida species and managed with topical or systemic antifungals depending on patient age and immune status.

  • The condition is generally secondary to immune suppression, which can be local or systemic, including extremes of age (newborns and elderly), immunocompromising diseases such as HIV/AIDS, and chronic systemic steroid and antibiotic use.

Management:

  • In Infants (Oral Thrush): Nystatin, amphotericin B, or miconazole gel is used topically multiple times a day.

In Adults:

  • Denture hygiene and removal at night are essential.
  • Topical therapies like lozenges or oral suspensions of nystatin, amphotericin, or miconazole work well for acute oral infections.
  • Treatment duration: Typically 10-14 days.
  • Chronic or Refractory Cases:
    • Fluconazole or itraconazole is more effective when topical therapy fails.
    • Alternative agents: Voriconazole or posaconazole.
    • Oral biopsy may be needed to rule out leukoplakia in persistent cases.

Management in Immunosuppressed Patients

  • Topical treatments often fail; systemic agents are preferred.
  • Short courses of fluconazole or itraconazole are recommended to prevent resistance.
  • Itraconazole solution or newer formulations like Lozanoc offer better absorption.
  • Voriconazole or posaconazole serve as alternatives for resistant or recurrent infections.

Vitamin supplements (Option A): Even though vitamin D3 has shown potential in preventing the formation of Candida biofilms, which are known to resist antifungal treatments due to their unique structural characteristics, only giving vitamin supplements will not cure oral candidiasis.

Biopsy for carcinoma (Option C) is done only in suspected cases and is not a first-line method of treatment.

Dapsone plus steroids (Option D) is not preferred in candidiasis as dapsone has an antimicrobial effect used for leprosy and dermatitis herpetiformis, but is ineffective here. Steroids are known risk factors for candidiasis and hence are not used.

questions.text: Visible desquamation of the stratum corneum is known as:
questions.solution: Scale: Visible desquamation of corneocytes (SC) (keratinocytes)

questions.text: Which disease is characterised by the findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The trichoscopy image from the alopecia areata, an autoimmune disease, shows the presence of hair with a broad distal tip and narrow/tapered proximal part. These are called exclamation mark hairs and are pathognomonic of alopecia areata.

Pathophysiology of Alopecia Areata:

In alopecia areata, a CD8+ T-cell-mediated attack targets anagen III-IV follicles, causing premature transition to telogen.

Follicles re-enter anagen but are repeatedly arrested at stage III-IV, leading to ineffective growth and recurrent hair loss.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The image shows features consistent with Acne inversa, also known as Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS), a chronic, relapsing inflammatory disease of apocrine gland-bearing areas.

Explanation of Othetr Options:

Acne Fulminans (Option B):

  • This is an acute, explosive form of nodulocystic acne that primarily affects adolescent males and presents with ulcerative, hemorrhagic nodules over the face, chest, back.
  • Unlike hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), acne fulminans has systemic features such as fever, malaise, and arthralgia; it lacks sinus tracts and rope-like scarring.

Acne Conglobata (Option C):

  • A chronic, severe variant of acne marked by grouped comedones, tender nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, and disfiguring hypertrophic or atrophic scars-commonly on the trunk, upper limbs, and buttocks. It lacks systemic symptoms.
  • Unlike HS, it does not show predilection for intertriginous areas (e.g., axillae, groin), lacks bridging scars, and typically presents with comedonal acne history rather than follicular occlusion alone.

Acne Vulgaris (Option D):

  • This is the most common form of acne, characterized by comedones, inflammatory papules, pustules, and occasional nodules, primarily affecting the face, chest, and back.
  • It may result in post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation or scarring but does not form sinus tracts or tunnels.

questions.text: The most common type of Leprosy in India is
questions.solution:
Borderline Tuberculoid s is the most frequently seen form of leprosy in India. It lies on the tuberculoid side of the Ridley-Jopling spectrum and is characterized by:

  • Few to several well-demarcated hypopigmented skin lesions
  • Asymmetric peripheral nerve involvement
  • Partial cell-mediated immunity - enough to limit bacterial proliferation, but not enough for complete clearance
  • Negative or weakly positive slit-skin smears
  • Pseudopodia like extensions

It is common in India due to the overall moderate immune response found in most individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae in endemic settings.

The upper arm of an Indian man showing a typical dry, hairless, hypopigmented plaque with a scaly, red edge. Such Lesions are usually anaesthetic.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tuberculoid Leprosy (Option A):
This form shows very strong cell-mediated immunity with typically one or two lesions and often a positive lepromin test.
Incorrect because it is less common than borderline tuberculoid in the population, though it may be seen in individuals with very robust immune responses.

Borderline Lepromatous (Option C):
This form is closer to the lepromatous pole and presents with more numerous and less defined lesions. It reflects a lower cell-mediated immunity.
Incorrect because it is less prevalent in India compared to borderline tuberculoid.

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option D):
This form occurs in patients with poor cell-mediated immunity. It shows widespread, symmetric lesions and a high bacillary load.
Incorrect because although common, it is not as frequent as borderline tuberculoid in India.

choices.text: Burrow is present in stratum granulosum
Burrow appears yellow on woods lamp
Burrows are located in the distribution - hebra circle
Burrow is a classical sign of scabies

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the Burrow of scabies except:
questions.solution:
• Scabies burrows are pathognomonic tunnels formed by the female Sarcoptes scabiei mite as it penetrates and moves within the stratum corneum, not the stratum granulosum.
  • In immunocompetent individuals, infestation with as few as 10-15 mites can cause the disease.
  • The typical incubation period is about 2-6 weeks in primary infestation (shorter in reinfestation due to hypersensitivity).
  • Burrows are typically found in the Hebra's circle and appear as serpiginous grayish lines.
  • Under Wood's lamp, they may fluoresce bluish-white, not yellow. Importantly, in animal scabies, though there can be intense pruritus, burrows are absent in human skin due to the inability of animal mites to complete their lifecycle in humans.

Explanation of other options:

Burrow appears yellow on woods lamp (Option B): Incorrect - scabies burrows fluoresce bluish-white, not yellow.

Burrows are located in the distribution - hebra circle (Option C): Correct - includes wrists, web spaces, genitalia, and axillae.

Burrow is a classical sign of scabies (Option D): Correct - burrows are the hallmark lesion, confirming diagnosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Burrows are found in the stratum corneum, not granulosum.
  • Disease may manifest with only 10-15 mites in immunocompetent hosts.
  • Burrows are absent in zoonotic (animal) scabies in humans.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a sexually transmitted infection?
questions.solution:
• Bacterial vaginosis is not considered as an STI. It is usually caused by imbalance between aerobic and anaerobic flora of the vagina.
  • However it is mostly seen in sexually active women, with new partner or multiple partners.
  • It is rare in virgins.

choices.text: Cell with hyperchromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo
Cell with hypochromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo

questions.text: The cell seen in Tzanck smear in pemphigus is:
questions.solution: • Acantholytic cells appear as round cells with perinuclear halo in Tzanck smear: Characteristic of Pemphigus

questions.text: The characteristic histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid is
questions.solution: In Bullous pemphigoid, histopathology will reveal a subepidermal split with abundant eosinophilic inflammatory infiltrate. Since there is no damage to desmosomes in bullous pemphigoid, there is no acantholysis seen. Thus, the blister is subepidermal, non-acantholytic.

questions.text: : A 34-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of multiple red, scaly plaques over his elbows, knees, and lower back. The lesions are well-demarcated, symmetrical, and have a silvery white scale. He reports that new lesions tend to appear at sites of minor cuts or scratches. His father has similar skin issues. Which of the following clinical signs best explains this?
questions.solution:
Appearance of psoriatic lesions at sites of trauma is known as the Koebner phenomenon, a hallmark feature of psoriasis.

  • The Koebner phenomenon (isomorphic response) refers to the development of typical lesions of a skin disease at sites of trauma, such as cuts, pressure, or friction.
  • Seen in psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.
  • It indicates active disease and may be precipitated by injury, tattooing, or scratching.
  • This patient has chronic plaque psoriasis, suggested by well-demarcated, scaly plaques over extensor surfaces and a family history.
  • The positive Koebner phenomenon helps differentiate psoriasis from other dermatoses.

Explanation of other options:

Nikolsky sign (Option A): Seen in pemphigus vulgaris; gentle rubbing causes epidermal separation.

Darier's sign (Option B): Urtication seen in mastocytosis upon stroking the lesion.

Auspitz sign (Option D): Pinpoint bleeding on removal of scales; also seen in psoriasis but not related to trauma-induced lesions.

Key Takeaway:

Koebner phenomenon is the development of psoriatic lesions at sites of trauma, indicative of active disease.

questions.text: What is the findings shown below ?
questions.solution: Pterygium unguis is the hallmark of severe nail disease. It results from a focal destruction of the nail matrix with subsequent scar formation. As the nail plate is not formed at the affected site, the epithelium of the proximal nail fold attaches itself directly to the nail bed epithelium and both grow distally together to produce a wing-like deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not nevus of melanocyte?
questions.solution:
Becker's nevus is not a nevus of a melanocyte

Becker Nevus

  • Appears as a hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth, caused by epidermal hyperpigmentation and increased androgen receptors, and not of melanocytic origin
  • Melanocytic nevi are lesions composed of nevus cells derived from melanocytes. Most are pigmented and appear due to the proliferation of these melanocytes or related cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male farmer from central India presents with chronic itching, erythematous scaly plaques on his face, neck, and forearms. He reports that the rash worsens with fieldwork, especially during the dry season. What is the most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
This is the most common cause of plant induced dermatitis (phytodermatitis) in India

Parthenium hysterophorus (Congress Grass) is the most common cause of phytodermatitis (plant-induced allergic contact dermatitis) in India.

  • Mechanism of Spread: It spreads primarily via airborne pollen and plant particles.
  • Clinical Presentation: Chronic exposure leads to airborne contact dermatitis, typically affecting exposed areas such as the face, neck, and forearms.
  • Key Allergenic Component: The major allergenic compounds responsible for its dermatitic effect are Sesquiterpene lactones.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cotton fibres (Option A): Cotton fibres may cause mechanical irritation but are not known to cause allergic phytodermatitis.

Poison ivy (Option B): While poison ivy is a well-known cause of phytodermatitis in North America, it is not prevalent in India.

Ragweed (Option D): Ragweed is a cause of allergic rhinitis (hay fever) in Western countries but is not a common agent of dermatitis in India.

Key Takeaway:

In India, Parthenium grass is the leading plant allergen causing airborne allergic contact dermatitis, especially in agricultural workers and rural populations.

questions.text: The clinical finding is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
Symptomatic dermographism, also known as dermographism urticaria or urticaria factitia, is an urticarial eruption upon pressure or trauma to the skin. The literal meaning is "to write on the skin." Downward pressure on the skin produces a linear wheal in the shape of the applied external force. Dermatographism is the most common type of inducible/physical urticaria, occurring in approximately 2% to 5% of the population.

Dermographism is essentially an exaggeration of this triple response. It has been postulated that it usually develops within five minutes of stroking the skin and persists for 15-30 min in contrast to the normal triple response of Lewis that subsides in less than 5-10 min

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Urticaria pigmentosa (Option A): Presents with fixed brownish macules/patches (mastocytosis), not transient wheals.

Cholinergic urticaria (Option C): Triggered by heat/sweat, causing small, pruritic papules rather than typical hives.

Urticarial vasculitis (Option D): Lesions last >24h with purpura/pigmentation, often painful (not itchy wheals).

questions.text: The most commonly involved internal organ in DRESS Syndrome is ______
questions.solution: Visceral involvement (hepatitis, pneumonitis, myocarditis, pericarditis, nephritis, and colitis) is the major cause of morbidity and mortality in this syndrome.

choices.text: It is the most common form of cutaneous lymphoma
Indolent course and good prognosis, easily amenable to treatment
Erythroderma seen and spreads to peripheral circulation

questions.text: Mycosis fungoides which is not true-
questions.solution:
1. Mycosis fungoides is an indolent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (indolent course. but is inevitably fatal (not easily amenable to treatment), except for patients in stage I.
  2. MF is the most common primary cutaneous lymphoma.
  3. Pautrier microabscess is characteristic of MF.
  4. Erythroderma can occur in MF (Sezary syndrome)

questions.text: Carpet tack sign is described in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Carpet tack sign is a characteristic sign of DLE. It is also known as "cat's tongue sign" or "tin tack sign"

It occurs due to the accumulation of scales in the hair follicles with resultant loss of hair. Later on, when scales are peeled off, typical keratotic spikes become visible producing characteristic "carpet-tack sign".

choices.text: Loss of function of NEMO Gene

questions.text: All are true regarding incontinentia pigmenti except?
questions.solution:
Incontinentia Pigmenti

X-linked dominant disorder, NEMO gene

Seen only in females

Lesions in blaschkoid pattern

Stages of skin lesion - VVHH

  • Vesicular: Initial stage, Usually occur in-utero
  • Verrucous: Broad linear bands of hyper keratotic papules
  • Hyperpigmentation: Typical whorls of brown to slate grey pigmentation
  • Hypopigmentation: atrophic hypopigmentation in same pattern

Associated abnormality:

  • Mental retardation, seizures, microcephaly
  • Skeletal abnormality
  • Delayed and abnormal dentition
  • Ocular defects in 33% of cases.

questions.text: Nevus simplex commonly presents on:
questions.solution:
Salmon Patch (Nevus Simplex)

MC vascular lesion of infancy

Presents as a flat salmon to pinkish patch that occurs frequently on the posterior neck, around the face and eyelids and glabellar region

These "stork bite" lesions usually fade on the face, but can persists around the orbit or back of the neck

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant, recently weaned from breastfeeding, presents with persistent diarrhoea, irritability, alopecia, and erythematous, crusted plaques involving the perioral, perianal, and acral areas. The lesions are sharply demarcated and show signs of secondary bacterial infection. What is the most likely underlying nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
This presentation is classic for acrodermatitis enteropathica, a rare inherited or acquired disorder due to zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SLC39A4 gene, which encodes ZIP4, the main intestinal transporter of zinc, resulting in impaired zinc absorption and systemic zinc deficiency.

  • Zinc is a vital cofactor for numerous enzymes, and its deficiency affects organs with high cell turnover: skin, intestine, and the immune system.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Dermatitis around the mouth, anus, hands, and feet, starting soon after weaning
    • Skin lesions: erythema, vesicles, bullae, pustules, desquamation, crusting
    • Alopecia, blepharitis, conjunctivitis, photophobia
    • Diarrhoea, growth faltering, and recurrent infections
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical features, low serum zinc (though it may be normal), and rapid response to zinc supplementation.
  • Treatment: Oral zinc sulphate 150-400 mg/day in children; requires lifelong supplementation.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • AE symptoms often begin at 4-10 weeks in formula-fed infants.
  • The disease can be fatal if untreated.
  • Monitoring for copper deficiency is necessary during treatment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Molybdenum (Option A):

Not implicated in acrodermatitis enteropathica. It's a trace element essential for enzyme function but not related to ZIP4 or skin disease.

Copper (Option B):

Copper deficiency can lead to haematological and neurological issues, but not the classical triad seen in AE (dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhoea).

Calcium (Option D):

Involved in bone and neuromuscular health; deficiency does not cause AE.

Key Takeaways:

  • AE is a genetic zinc absorption disorder caused by SLC39A4 mutations.
  • Presents with periorificial/acral dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhoea in infants.
  • Treatment is lifelong zinc supplementation, starting from infancy.
